back_cards.definition_en: A unit of language with meaning.
back_cards.example_en: She wrote a new word in her notebook.
He gave his word to finish the project.

back_cards.definition_en: A term used in a specific field.
back_cards.example_en: The word 'byte' is common in computing.
Can I have a word with you in private?
Have you heard any word about the storm?
The fact that it rained surprised everyone.
She checked the facts before her presentation.
It's a fact that the river is polluted.

back_cards.definition_en: A detail used in an argument.
back_cards.example_en: He used facts to win the debate.
The fact of his arrival thrilled the team.
You got the right answer on the test.
It’s right to help those in need.
She’s the right person for the job.

back_cards.definition_en: Located on the side opposite to left.
back_cards.example_en: Turn right at the next street.
The machine is working right now.

back_cards.definition_en: To look at and understand written text.
back_cards.example_en: She loves to read novels in the evening.
He can read the weather by the clouds.

back_cards.definition_en: To study or learn from text.
back_cards.example_en: They read about dinosaurs in class.
The teacher read a story to the kids.
The thermometer read 98 degrees.
Do you need anything from the store?
She didn’t say anything during the meeting.
You can pick anything from the menu.
Anything can happen in this game.
He didn’t find anything in the drawer.
There was nothing left in the fridge.
It was nothing, just a small mistake.
Nothing grows in the desert sand.
She ate nothing for breakfast.
Nothing will stop us from hiking.
I’m sure we’ll find the park soon.
This is a sure way to save money.
Sure, I’ll join you for coffee.
It’s sure to rain this afternoon.
The knot is sure and tight.
She lives in a small apartment.
It’s just a small problem, don’t worry.
He took a small sip of water.
The small puppy ran around the yard.
The town has a small population.
We’ll move next month.

back_cards.definition_en: A unit of time in a calendar.
back_cards.example_en: February is the shortest month.
She trained for a month before the race.
The rent is due every month.
This month has been very rainy.
The school has a new sports program.

back_cards.definition_en: A set of instructions for a computer.
back_cards.example_en: He wrote a program to track expenses.
Her favorite program airs tonight.
The training program starts tomorrow.
The festival program includes music.
Maybe it will rain this afternoon.
She said maybe she’d join us later.
Maybe we can finish early today.
Maybe we’ll go hiking tomorrow.
Maybe that’s not the best idea.
The store is right around the corner.
I’ll call you right after the meeting.
She answered the question right.
Look right before crossing the road.
The car broke down right in traffic.
The cat hid under the table.
The trip costs under $100.
She works under a strict boss.
The bridge is under construction.
The keys were under a pile of papers.
She started a small business selling crafts.
He’s on a business trip this week.
This is none of your business.

back_cards.definition_en: The activity of buying and selling.
back_cards.example_en: The market is good for business.
The family business has grown.
She went home after work.
Their home is always welcoming.
The mountains are my home.
They bought a new home last year.
He ran to home plate in baseball.
What kind of music do you like?
This kind of flower blooms in spring.
They sell all kinds of snacks.
He’s not that kind of person.

back_cards.definition_en: Used to refer to a general type.
back_cards.example_en: This kind of weather is unusual.
The car stopped at the red light.
She stopped talking when he entered.
They stopped the leak in the pipe.
Let’s stop for lunch on the way.
He stopped smoking last year.

back_cards.definition_en: To give money for goods or services.
back_cards.example_en: She paid for the groceries with cash.

back_cards.definition_en: To settle a debt or bill.
back_cards.example_en: He paid the rent on time.
The job pays well for the hours.

back_cards.definition_en: To bear a cost or penalty.
back_cards.example_en: They paid a fine for speeding.
Pay attention during the lecture.
She studies biology at college.
He studied all night for the exam.
They studied the stars through a telescope.
She studies her lines for the play.
The team studied the effects of pollution.

back_cards.definition_en: From a past time until now.
back_cards.example_en: She’s lived here since 2010.
He’s been quiet since the meeting.
They’ve grown closer since last summer.
Since it’s raining, we’ll stay inside.
The shop has been open since morning.
The team discussed the issue of delays.
The issue of climate change is critical.
I read the latest issue of the magazine.
The issue of the vote was a tie.
Money was the main issue in the talks.

back_cards.definition_en: A word identifying a person or thing.
back_cards.example_en: Her name is Sarah.
The name of the book is on the cover.
He made a name for himself in art.
What’s the name of that flower?
The team picked a name for the project.
She had an idea for a new app.
His idea was to hike at dawn.
I like the idea of working remotely.
The idea of summer excites her.
The idea behind the event was charity.

back_cards.definition_en: A space or area in a building.
back_cards.example_en: The living room is cozy.

back_cards.definition_en: A specific area for a purpose.
back_cards.example_en: She booked a room for the meeting.
Is there room for one more chair?
The kids share a room upstairs.
There’s room for improvement here.
Ten percent of the class was absent.
The tax is five percent of the price.
A high percent of voters turned out.
The survey showed 60 percent approval.
Sales dropped by 20 percent.
The town is far from the city.
She’s far better at math than I am.
He threw the ball far into the field.
The stars seem far away tonight.
They’ve come far in their research.

back_cards.definition_en: At a distance from a place.
back_cards.example_en: She moved away from the noise.
He’s away on a business trip.
The bird flew away from danger.
Put the toys away before dinner.
They worked away all afternoon.
The new law bans plastic bags.
She studied law at university.
The law of gravity is universal.
He works in law as a lawyer.
It’s the law to wear seatbelts.
It’s actually colder than it looks.
Actually, I meant tomorrow, not today.
She actually finished the race first.
He’s actually a great cook.
The plan actually worked perfectly.
They live in a large house.
The company has a large workforce.
The park has a large open field.
It was a large step for the team.
A large crowd gathered outside.
It was sunny, though it was cold.
She tried hard, though she didn’t win.
He’s kind, though a bit shy.
It’s risky, though worth trying.
I’ll go, though I’m tired.
The school provides free lunches.
They provide tools for the job.
He provides for his family.
The app provides real-time updates.
The law provides for safety measures.
She lost her keys in the park.
The team lost the game yesterday.
He lost his job last month.
She’s trying to lose weight.
Don’t lose your chance to apply.
The engine has a lot of power.
The mayor holds power in the city.
The storm cut off the power.
Her voice has the power to inspire.
The media has great power.
The kid played in the sandbox.
She’s a smart kid in math class.
The goat had two kids this spring.
He’s a good kid at heart.
The kids had fun at the party.
The war lasted for three years.
The trade war hurt the economy.
There’s a war on plastic waste.
He studied the history of war.
The war against crime continues.
I understand the instructions clearly.
She understands how the machine works.
He understands why she’s upset.
They understand the poem differently.
I understand you’re leaving soon.

back_cards.definition_en: The top part of the body.
back_cards.example_en: She wore a hat on her head.
He’s the head of the department.
The head of the line moved forward.
Keep a clear head during the test.
The farm has 50 head of cattle.
Her mother baked cookies today.
The river is the mother of the valley.
She’s like a mother to the team.
Mother Nature gave us a sunny day.
Necessity is the mother of invention.
This is a real diamond ring.
He’s a real friend when you need one.
The threat is real and serious.
The cake is made with real butter.
Her smile was real and warm.
This is the best coffee in town.
She’s the best candidate for the role.
He gave his best effort in the race.
The best time to visit is spring.
They’re the best team in the league.
The soccer team won the match.
Our team finished the project early.
She joined the debate team.
The team cleaned the park.
The rescue team saved the hikers.
Her blue eyes sparkled in the sun.
In my eye, the plan is risky.
Keep an eye on the kids.
The eye of the storm was calm.
The needle has a tiny eye.
The bridge is very long.
It was a long day at work.
The road trip was long and tiring.
She waited a long time for the bus.
The snake has a long body.
They talked long into the night.
She hasn’t visited in long.
Long ago, this was a forest.
The movie ran long past midnight.
He stayed long after the party.
The box has a red side.
She stood on the left side of the stage.
Which side are you on in the debate?
The bright side of the plan is its cost.
The house is by the side of the river.
She drank a glass of water.
The lake’s water was clear.
The town needs clean water.
They sailed on the open water.
The plant needs water to grow.

back_cards.definition_en: Having lived for a short time.
back_cards.example_en: The young puppy was playful.
She has a young spirit at heart.
The young tree needs support.
The young couple moved to the city.
Young leaves appeared in spring.
We waited for the bus in the rain.
Wait a minute before you leave.
She’s waiting for her test results.
He waits tables at the café.
The car waited outside the store.
The food was okay, not great.
She’s okay after the minor fall.
It’s okay to bring a friend.
The plan seems okay to me.
Okay, let’s start the meeting.

back_cards.definition_en: Referring to two things or people.
back_cards.example_en: Both of them went to the party.
Both books are on the shelf.
Both teams played well.
Both sides agreed to the terms.
Both kids shared the toy.
She hasn’t finished her homework yet.
It’s the best movie I’ve seen yet.
We may succeed yet.
He’s tired, yet he keeps working.
The sun hasn’t set yet.
We’ll meet after the movie.
She walked after him in the parade.
He ran after the bus.
They asked after her health.
The town was named after a hero.
Let’s meet at the café.
I met an old friend yesterday.
The plan meets our needs.
The club meets every Tuesday.
She met challenges during the project.
The restaurant offers great service.
The bus service runs hourly.
He did it as a service to the team.
The church held a special service.
She retired after years of service.
The park is a green area.
The kitchen area is small.
Her area of expertise is biology.
This area gets heavy snow.
The area of the rug is large.
This meeting is very important.
Her role is important to the team.
It’s important to stay hydrated.
He’s an important figure in history.
Safety is the most important thing.
She’s a kindest person I know.
One person can make a difference.
He’s a quiet person at work.
The law applies to every person.
A person who called didn’t leave a name.
Hey, how’s it going?
Hey, come look at this view!
Hey, I didn’t know you could sing!
Hey, don’t forget your bag!
Hey, good to see you again!
I thank you for the lovely gift.

back_cards.definition_en: She thanked the team for their help.

back_cards.example_en: He thanked her for the ride home.
They thanked the volunteers.
We thank our sponsors for support.
